content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V that manage federal real property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. It also includes provisions on Cuba sanctions and funding for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, and judiciary. The FSGG appropriations bill funds various government agencies, including the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. It also addresses Cuba sanctions and contains general provisions that apply government-wide. Additionally, the bill occasionally covers financial regulation issues in additional titles. The FSGG appropriations bill funds government agencies like the Department of the Treasury and the judiciary. It also addresses Cuba sanctions and occasionally covers financial regulation issues. The bill has existed in its current form since 2007 and funds the same agencies in both the House and Senate, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which is funded differently. The House and Senate FSGG bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) which is funded differently. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG appropriations bill, with $330 million allocated for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018 on July 18, 2017. The total funding for the FSGG independent agencies in the reported bill would have been $253 million, with an additional $248 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill. This combined total of $501 million would have been about $2.6 billion below the President's FY2018 request. The Agriculture appropriations bill (H.R. 3268, H.Rept. 115-232) included $501 million in funding, $2.6 billion below the President's FY2018 request. Most of the difference was in funding for the General Services Administration (GSA).
